## My summary of reading EJS.


# What is a EJS:

![EJS](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

EJS simply stands for Embedded Javascript. It is a simple templating language/engine that lets its user generate HTML with plain javascript.

EJS is mostly useful whenever you have to output HTML with a lot of javascript.
EJS is compatible with Express for back-end use as it hooks into the View engine architecture that Express provides and lets you render web pages to the client with res.render() in Express.

# STEPS TO DEAL WITH IT.

First of all let’s move to the steps to install and prepare EJS to work with:

1- Install EJS
npm i ejs

2- Set up the view engine and the views directory
// view engine setup
app.set('views', path.join(__dirname, 'views'));
app.set('view engine', 'ejs');

3- Set up our public folder for static files
//setup public folder
app.use(express.static('./public'));

4- Add the ‘/’ route to render the views/pages/home.ejs page
app.get('/',function (req, res) {
res.render('pages/home')
});

# Why do we use it 
1- Use plain JavaScript

2- We love JavaScript. It’s a totally friendly language. All templating languages grow to be Turing-complete. Just cut out the middle-man, and use JS!
Active development

3- EJS has a large community of active users, and the library is under active development. We’re happy to answer your questions or give you help.
Fast development time

4- Don’t waste time and attention figuring out arcane new syntax because ‘elegance’ — or how to preprocess your data so it will actually render right.
Speedy execution

5- We all know how fast V8 and the other JavaScript runtimes have gotten. EJS caches the intermediate JS functions for fast execution.
Simple syntax

6- JavaScript code in simple, straightforward scriptlet tags. Just write JavaScript that emits the HTML you want, and get the job done!
Easy debugging

7- It’s easy to debug EJS errors: your errors are plain JavaScript exceptions, with template line-numbers included.
# And that was it for this summary.
